The increased population density would lead to higher demand for housing, leading to the development of vertical living spaces such as high-rise buildings and skyscrapers. This could also lead to the need for more efficient public transportation systems to accommodate the increased number of people.

The concentration of resources and population in a single city could lead to increased competition for resources such as food, water, and energy. This could lead to the development of more sustainable and efficient technologies to meet these needs.
The increased population density could also lead to a greater focus on public health and sanitation, as well as the need for more efficient waste management systems.

The concentration of resources and population in a single city could also lead to a greater focus on education and innovation, as people would have access to more resources and opportunities for learning and development.

The increased population density could also lead to a greater focus on environmental sustainability and preservation, as the impact of human activities on the environment would be more concentrated in a single city.
